title: Grocery Store Fresh Produce Delivery Problem
content: A regional farm supplies fresh fruits and vegetables to <num_customer> grocery stores from its packing facility at <loc_depot>. Their refrigerated trucks can carry up to <capacity> kg of perishable goods per trip. Each store (<loc_customer>) orders a different amount (<demand> kg) based on daily sales. The farm needs to deliver everything in one morning to keep produce fresh, but trucks can’t be overloaded. The goal? Plan routes so all stores get their orders, no truck exceeds capacity, and the total distance driven is as short as possible—saving fuel and keeping strawberries crisp!

title: Pharmacy Vaccine Distribution Problem
content: A medical warehouse at <loc_depot> must deliver temperature-sensitive vaccines to <num_customer> clinics (<loc_customer>) using coolers in vans (max <capacity> doses per trip). Each clinic needs a specific number of doses (<demand>) for the week. Since vaccines expire quickly, every clinic must be visited exactly once, and vans can’t mix shipments due to safety rules. The team wants to minimize travel time to ensure doses stay cold and reach clinics ASAP. Tight capacity and urgency make this a high-stakes routing puzzle!

title: Office Printer Maintenance Problem
content: A tech company services <num_customer> office buildings (<loc_customer>) with printers that need monthly toner replacements (<demand> cartridges per building). Their technicians start at the depot (<loc_depot>) with vans that fit <capacity> cartridges. Each building must be visited once, and no van can carry more toner than its limit. To reduce downtime, they aim to optimize routes so technicians spend less time driving and more time fixing printers—saving both mileage and frustrated employees!

title: Charity Food Bank Collection Problem
content: A food bank at <loc_depot> coordinates daily pickups of donated groceries from <num_customer> supermarkets (<loc_customer>). Each store has a different amount (<demand> kg) to donate, and the food bank’s trucks hold up to <capacity> kg. Volunteers need to collect all donations in one trip per store without overloading trucks, while minimizing distance to save on fuel (and spend more funds on meals for the needy!). Rain or shine, those routes must be efficient!

title: Flower Shop Wedding Deliveries Problem
content:
A florist at <loc_depot> has <num_customer> wedding venues (<loc_customer>) needing bouquets and centerpieces (<demand> arrangements per venue) on the same Saturday. Their delivery vans can only fit <capacity> fragile arrangements at once. Since flowers wilt and weddings can’t wait, the florist must design routes where:  
- Every venue gets their order in one go.  
- No van is overstuffed (or roses get crushed!).  
- Drivers take the shortest paths to keep bouquets fresh.  
One wrong turn could mean wilted peonies and a very unhappy bride!

title: Mobile Library Delivery Problem
content:
A county library system operates a fleet of mobile library vans that bring books to rural communities (<loc_customer>) from a central depot (<loc_depot>).  
Each van can carry up to <capacity> books, and every stop has a unique request (<demand>)—some want children’s books, others need large-print editions.  
The goal is to plan routes so that:  
✓ No van is overloaded.  
✓ Every community gets their requested books in one visit.  
✓ The total driving distance is minimized to save fuel and time.  
Since some villages are far apart, efficient routing ensures librarians spend more time with readers and less time on the road.

title: E-Waste Recycling Collection Problem
content:
An eco-friendly company collects old electronics (laptops, phones, etc.) from <num_customer> drop-off points (<loc_customer>) using trucks with a <capacity> weight limit.

They need routes that:  
✓ Avoid sending half-empty trucks (wasting fuel).  
✓ Cover all stops without exceeding truck capacity.  
✓ Minimize total distance to reduce emissions.  
Efficient planning means more gadgets get recycled, and fewer trucks clog up city streets.

title: Farm-to-Table Produce Delivery Problem

content:

title: Mobile Coffee Cart Refueling Problem

The goal is to design routes that refill every cart exactly once, keep vans within their limits, and minimize total driving distance—so baristas never hear "Sorry, we’re out of oat milk!"
